item.title: Start With PHP
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Add this please. I tested the documents before posting.

[size=10pt]POST[/size]

Edit: POST Test. Link

POST is like GET except when you use POST the variables and data don’t get sent in the URL. Instead they are stored in your cache, and then extracted and sent to the next page. So if you went to index.php in this example, typed in something in the box, you would get sent to index2.php and whatever you typed in would be shown and it would still be index2.php at the address bar.

index.php should have…

<html>
<head>
<title>POST Example -> index.php</title>
</head>
<body>
<form method="post" action="index2.php">
  <!-- Look at this Input tag. It has a name of msg. This will be our POST name. -->
  Message: <input type="text" name="msg" /> <br />
  <input type="submit" value="Submit" />
</form>
</body>
</html>

index2.php should have…

<?
 // Sets the variable $message equal to the POST variable of 'msg'.
 // 'msg' is the name of our Input Box in index.php.
 $message = $_POST['msg'];
 
 // Check to see if the variable $message equals nothing.
 // If it does equal nothing, then send the user back to index.php.
 If ($message == "") {
   header('Location: index.php');
 }
?>
<html>
<head>
<title>POST Example -> index2.php</title>
</head>
<body>
 <!-- Sends whatever is in the variable $message. -->
 Message: <?=$message;?>
</body>
</html>

POST is generally used for usernames/passwords/user options/ and stuff like that.

~Ron

item.dc:creator: @Drunkenoldma Drunkenoldma
item.description:
@Drunkenoldma wrote:

[size=15pt]Start With PHP[/size] [size=8pt]By Drunkenoldma[/size]

Hey all, I will teach you how to start with php.

Requirements

[ul][li]PHP Host, or an apache with PHP installed on (I suggest EasyPHP or XAMPP)[/li]
[li]A text editor (I suggest Notepad++, or standard notepad) or a WYSIWYG editor (Dreamweaver, Adobe GoLive, …)[/li]
[li]HTML knowledge[/li][/ul]

[size=10pt]Hello world [/size]
[right][size=8pt]php.net link[/size][/right]
I’m going to start with the cliché, a hello world exercise.
Open your favourite texteditor, and typ in:

<?php echo "Hello World!"; ?>
Now save as ‘index.php’ (and if you use a host, upload it to your host.), and point your browser to the file.

Output:
[hr]
Hello World!
[hr]

Now, you are able to put html inside the echo to:

<?php echo "<b>Hello</b> <i>World!</i>"; ?>
Would output this:
[hr]
Hello World!
[hr]
Let’s go on…

[size=10pt]Variables[/size]
[right][size=8pt]php.net link[/size][/right]
Now that you’ve learned how to print stuff, it’s time to learn how to use variables.

Let’s first look at a code:

<?php $name = "Drunkenoldma"; echo "Hello, $name"; ?>
Yes, you guessed right, this outputs:
[hr]
Hello, Drunkenoldma
[hr]

[size=10pt]If[/size]
[right][size=8pt]php.net link[/size][/right]
You learned how to make variables, now you can use them in an if-function.

<?php $name = "Drunkenoldma"; if($name == "Drunkenoldma"){ echo "Hello coolguy =P"; } else { echo "You aren't drunkenoldma"; } ?>

Now it checks if the variable $name equals Drunkenoldma, if it does, then it outputs
[hr]
Hello coolguy =P
[hr]

If the variable $name would be something else then Drunkenoldma, this would output:
[hr]
You aren’t drunkenoldma
[hr]

Now, this is kinda Pointless, because you set a variable in the script…

[size=10pt]GET[/size]
[right][size=8pt]php.net link[/size][/right]

<?php
echo 'Your name is '.$_GET['name'].'.';
?>

Now, when you go to ‘index.php?name=drunkenoldma’, this will output:
[hr]
Your name is drunkenoldma
[hr]

GET can be used in If’s too:

<?php
if($_GET['name'] == "drunkenoldma"){
  echo "Hello, drunkenoldma, you rock";
} else {
  echo "Hello, '.$_GET['name'].', you don't rock";
}
?>
